segments.text: is that George, in my judgment, is one of the truly unusual captains of industry in our country, indeed in the world.
He has an intellectual curiosity that's refreshing.
He's not just focused on the business.
He's really interested in a broad spectrum of human life.
He's incredibly bright.
He's got a memory like a steel trap.
And I really have grown to love him and respect him because of that.
He's a humanist.
He has an interest in the globe.
He's unusual.
And it's not well known.
He's not perceived that way.
No, not the outside.
Inside, yes.
We get this pretty consistently.
The guy's brutally honest with himself and with everybody else.
So in that sense, you would not be surprised.
Thank you, Donna.
You're welcome.
You would not be surprised once you know this about him.
That he does these things.
That he would be interested in such a project.
Good.
And not be daunted by the challenge.
That's another side of the George Mitchell story.
Yeah.
That's pretty impressive.
Yeah, you bet.
A person who's become
A good friend of mine over, since I've been at HAARC, is from Switzerland named Luke Tissot.
And Luke and I spend a fair amount of time talking about this cultural difference between our sectors of society.
And this trip to Eastern Europe a couple weeks ago, we were together.
We spoke of this again.
And I'm reminded of our discussion
at this point about George is that in the academic world, when you're sitting around and having a collegial discussion, the important thing is to have a good problem.
And what people want to know is, what's your problem?
What are you working on?
What are you trying to solve?
But the focus is on the problem.
That's right.
And in the business world,
You are a deliverer of good solutions.
And in the academic world, you're a deliverer of good problems.
And it really is clean, and it really clarifies it.
And people that can do both are rare, rare, rare.
Because the worst thing to have happen in the academic world is
to come up with an elegant solution that destroys your problem.
Particularly if it's worth money.
That's why more study is needed, isn't it?
I mean, if you make money doing it, I mean, you're really screwed up.
That's right.
So then you look like one of them instead of one of us.
And the economic feeding chain is not well understood, or not even interested, typically, in being understood in our traditional
academic world, and that has to change.
And it is changing.
And if we can lead the change, rather than wait until economic reality forces the change, we can anticipate and initiate to cause it before it hits us and forces it.
See, our government's out of control.
I mean, it's embarrassing to be from this country right now.
And these guys in our congressional
representatives in both the Senate and the House.
They just can't believe the reality of where they are.
And hence, they can't deal with it.
They cannot deal with it.
And finally, it'll get dealt with by the laws of Mother Nature, not through leadership.
Who was it that said, change happens in a democracy by two ways, leadership, crisis, and mostly by crisis?
But see, George would take this challenge on.
Yeah.
as an interesting problem that needs a solution, let's go get the solution.
And he just goes after the solution.
And indeed, in fact, the whole concept of it seems to be the idea that he is going to manage change over a very long period.
You bet.
And he's creating a town here.
It's a vision.
This isn't a real estate project.
He's creating a town.
So let's put the super glider back into that.
Yeah, so the super glider was

project that at an executive committee meeting of Hark's board on which I served I said okay this is a project which is arisen on the campus of Texas A&M as an official of that institution I'm empowered
to commit that institution, backing fully for this institution, to take the lead.
And I commit to HARC that Texas A&M will do whatever it can to back HARC's lead in taking on the proposal for the super plan.
And the executive committee voted that that was a good project for HARC to do.
took it on and I went back and at the next executive committee meeting at A&M, I said, by the way, I could tell you what I did.
And everybody said, wonderful Porter, that's why we put you on the board.
You know?
So, uh, I said, well, we're committed.
Everybody said, great.
Just tell us what we need to do next.
And so we created then in the fall, in the spring of 1984 to get us back in the time and to get me here, which is where you want to go.
the Texas Accelerator Center as an arm of PARCC.
OK. That is now before?
Before I come.
I think that's March of 84.
And about that time.
So right now, PARCC is an entity.
And HARC, and you're on the board, and HARC is looking at a super collider, a super computer, and the Texas Accelerator Center.
Well, the Texas Accelerator Center and the super collider are one and the same project.
The Texas Accelerator Center is the formal mechanism to pursue the super collider.
And so HARC agrees to commit $1.6 million to support the establishment
of the Texas Accelerator Center at HARC.
And where is that money coming from?
It's coming from the endowment, or not endowment, but the budgetary commitment to HARC from George.
Is there any university money in that pot?
None.
Not in that $1.6 million.
Now, several of the universities also committed financial support to the team.
And I think Texas A&M ended up with

In the final analysis, I don't know when you say final analysis, but over the period of a few years after I did come, it was something like a million dollars total when HAARC had maybe five million total in it.
So now the accelerator center is launched.
The supercomputer proposal is in preparation and being submitted.

And the laser center, Doctors Margrave and Barry from Rice, have an opportunity to go after a contract that is classified, or could be classified, when it is not permitted on Rice University's campus.
As HARC is an outlet for faculty that wants to do proprietary and classified research, they turn to HARC to say, gee, can we move this to HARC.
Which is the purpose of HARC.
That's right.
And so the Laser Applications Research Center, or what would become the Laser Applications Research Center, begins.
This is also in 84.
So at this point in time, HARCs begin to have some things.
The executive committee says, oh, and also we have a big glitch with Harvey McMains, who turns out to claim to be several things he wasn't.
There's a big embarrassment, and he's invited to leave.
And so he leaves, and the board decides, boy, there's some things that look like could really begin here.
We need to get some, sure enough, leadership full time.
Hydric and Struggles is hired.
Who is that?
Hydric and Struggles, executive search firm.
They're hired to do a search to find a president.
And George comes to me and says, I'd like to nominate you to become the president of Harvard.
And this is in the summer of 84.
And he says, following that, or maybe at that time, that he's talked, or he will talk, or he wants to talk.
to Hanson and Vandiver to be sure this is comfortable with him, for him to even do this, that he doesn't want to make them mad about recruiting somebody away from there, et cetera, et cetera.
And I'll tell him, I'm not sure I'm interested in the job, but I'll think about it.
Because I've been through this a couple times now in my life.
So that's when I really sit down and,
reflect on what I've already just finished telling you about the history of A&M.
And so I'll talk to George some more about really what his view is.
And this is where I begin to get this vision myself.

Damn, I think maybe Mitchell from the industry sector of our society has been having the same kind of feelings and visions of what's needed that I've been having over here in the higher education sector.
and that there might be a coming together out here.
So we talked some more, and I went off to Scotland for a week to really think about it, and decided that, well, I didn't have anything to lose to agree to look at it.
So I agreed to be a candidate.
And so then they did a nationwide search.
And when the smoke cleared, I got offered the job.
Which was?
Which was what's interesting, because there was going to be a meeting of the full board of HART
in November of 84.
And George wanted my answer by the first of November, so he could have all of this officially formally ratified at that board meeting and have the board there to meet me.
See, I'd never met the board.
The telephone board, you've never met the board?
No, yeah, I mean there was George and myself and John Margrave from Rice and
David Gottlieb from U of H, and I don't even believe we had anybody from UT at that time.
Maybe Jerry Funkin was coming on.
And a guy named Mitchell.
Gee, I don't know why I can't think of his name right now.
Colson Tuff.
And Colson was actually on the board.
And that was the executive committee.
And during this period of time, David Gottlieb stepped in as interim president or acting president because McBain's had left and the search was on.
So George and I got together downtown, I remember, in his office finally in late October and finally hammered out the agreement on me coming here.
And I agreed and then I came down for the meeting in November and began
on like a day a week to transition from College Station to here in November and December.
And then I moved here January 1st, 1985.
And Biddy stayed in College Station because Paige was a senior in high school.
So she was there through the summer.
I lived here in just the apartment for the first six months.
which worked out to be great because that's all I did was work.
Because HARC was an office in a rental building with a secretary down on Grover's Mill, the accelerator center was coming together.
It had been operational some six or nine months at that point in time.
The team was assembling and equipment was coming in.
Things were being set up.
We've been successful in receiving a $4 million contract from DOE to do magnet design.
I showed up here in January on a full-time basis.
And you were in.
Pretty much.
You and your secretary.
I was in.
We had that contract.
I mean, there really hadn't been any leadership.
Nobody knew how to run such an institution or organization.
We had a $4 million contract from DOE.
Books had been kept on the back of envelopes.
We had an audit, DOE audit, coming up.
It was a mess.
I mean, a big time mess.
And fortunately, most of, within the next
12 months, most of a rather excellent team that I had managed to put together for the engineering experiment station.
So one by one came down here and said, gee, you've got a job.
And most of them are here.
And so HART got a real leveraged management structure benefit by the fact that
the team that had been building the Engineering Experiment Station wanted to do this very risky thing down here.
And you're doing basically the same things you were doing at Texas A&M, but you're in the private sector.
Or is that a fair?
Yeah, I think that's fair.
You're working with the same structures.
You work in academia, state government.
in the private industry, but now you're working in this industry?
From the private sector side.
And my extrapolation that I mentioned earlier, that private makes a difference, does.
It's a breath of fresh air.
There's almost a self-imposed cloak of concern about
the public, protecting the public.
I mean, there really is an importance.
There's a fiduciary responsibility there that I'm not sure how to describe it, but it's real.
But at heart, I'm doing this now not to say that this last five years hasn't been really interesting.
I've probably learned more in the last five years than I've learned in the previous 50 or 40 or whatever it is.
But at any rate, dealing with four institutions now instead of one.
Is it more now that you're cooperating with them as volunteer organizations out there?
Well, as associates, what kind of relationship do you describe?
OK, it's matured and it's evolved, both.
Initially, HARC was owned by the four founders, which at that point in time were the four.
HARC had a 29-member board, four
board members from each of the four founding institutions formed 16 members of this 29, and then the others were pretty much elected.
In most cases, many if not most, these were faculty members that never served on a board of anything, certainly a corporate board, an institutional board.
So you're really in the same situation in a way, mentally, that you left Texas A&M?
In some ways, the board members are there more to protect the interest of their home institutions as opposed to build a new one, which you could understand.
And with a culture of...
Their institution is the most important thing.
It was intriguing and interesting to come to these meetings because they could see and watch their colleagues from other institutions.
But coming to HARC with a HARC hat to build HARC as a board member with fiduciary board member responsibilities responsible to the publics that support HARC isn't even in the mental
perspective of most of these people.
They don't have a perspective of what that means.
And they're even collaborating, working at it before anyway.
Well, but never certainly been on the board of a non-profit institution where you have a fiduciary responsibility to the public that supports it.
And also, that structure began to create

particularly, I think, for the University of Texas and Texas A&M, who perceive themselves as big enough to do anything alone, almost always, that if HARC, with one of the other institutions, went after
a contract that they wanted to go after individually.
There was the opportunity for the contractor to come to the conclusion that if they funded HARC, they would be funding the other institution anyway, since the other institution owned HARC.
which put them in the awkward and uncomfortable position of kind of competing with themselves.
And very understandable.
And so Bill Cunningham in particular got uncomfortable about that, which I understood and concurred with.
And until Hark was Hark, not
the sibling or the slave, so to speak.

So until HARC was HARC, as really an independent institution, that these collaborative institutions could on their own initiative, when they wanted to, when they felt it was to their benefit, decide to come
when we requested or when they requested and said, hey, let's do this deal together.
And when they didn't, they didn't.
And it was just clean.

And we could get a smaller board of experienced people, but without losing, and nobody wanted to lose any of the sense that these institutions were in any way withdrawing from HARC or their commitment.
So in one-on-one sessions with each of the presidents of the universities, I talked through this with each one of them.
Our individual and then collective agreement was that we would change it.
Hark would be owned by Hark, not by them.
Now, who appoints?
Does the president still appoint?
No.
You make that appointment?
No.
The new bylaws are we have a 15-member board.
The president of HARC, Texas A&M, Reich, UT Austin, and University of Houston all serve on HARC's board.
Oh, OK. And then 10 members are elected.
OK.
So by having the presidents of those institutions serve on HARC's board, it still makes a very strong commitment of the institution.
Certainly does.
And we've got another level of experienced person
as opposed to just a double E professor who's asked to serve.
When did that change?
Last year.
Now, do you see Hart then as a, what's your view of Hart in terms of the Houston economic community, the Texas community, the regional, whatever?
Where are you in terms of this whole complex?
Well.
You don't really see a woodlands entity here particularly at all.
Woodlands only.
Yeah, I mean, you have little to do.
You just happen to reside in one of those.
That's it.
Okay, that's good.
No, and I have a very, very global view of this.
Yeah, that's what I mean.
Which is probably so big that most people, A, would scoff at it because, E, it's too big, or, B, it's not understandable.
Well, here in super colliders and supercomputers, you know, that's pretty big.
Stop.
And I assume you're going beyond that.
Yeah, we are.
At least that's my intention.

But my view is that, and this is a global view, there's going to be maybe a dozen, probably less, regions on Earth that are going to be meaningful communities where bright people can really make things happen.
And there's enough infrastructure and understanding of what to do with what I call an intellectual product.
That America.
You and your man are helping build that infrastructure.
For the nation.
But it happens to be domiciled.
It's just circumstantial that it's here.
I think it's the right place to be.
Now, do you think Research Center is in North Carolina or Silicon Valley?
Does any of that really enter into your thinking as a model?
No, not much.
I know it does more in Georgia than mine.
But I think my view of this is much more global than George's.
Which sometimes bothers me, because I have great respect for George's view.
But George doesn't see things much international, doesn't really much like the international sense of things.
Rarely travels outside of the country.
But that's not a criticism, it's an observation.

His interest in the globe and global issues is well known and certainly he's an unusual thinker on things like energy from a global perspective and population control and the environment and those issues and very much interested in those issues and independently supports and involves himself with that.
This goes back to my personal gut-level feeling of 20 years ago, at least, is that we as a nation have got to do something more in the economic feeding chain.

And those of us that have had the benefit of an education and have an opportunity, particularly from a science and technology point of view, to do something about turning these ideas into meaningful value-added products have got to do something more than sit behind the hedges.

I guess this really began to settle in on me when I was arguing for the budgets in the Texas legislature and getting a first-hand view of all the other demands on the tax dollar and thinking through the feeding chain.
If there weren't a lot of healthy Texas instruments out there, there weren't a lot of healthy people living up and down the streets that we all live on,

with enough money to send their kids to college, who we could then, as professors, have the privilege of training, who could then go out and use their logically trained minds to generate in a competitive way new products and new jobs that pay the taxes, that send the money to Austin, that give it back to the universities in the line-iron budget.
And the worst thing that we could do would be to quit working with the source of the funds that feed us.
And that feeding chain is just not understood on a campus.
Money just comes from somewhere.
They owe it to us because God sent me here as an educated person to do good things.
I'm trying to develop really as much for our nation as for our state or our city, although I believe we're in the right state and the best city to do it.
And I think we're in the best part of the city to do it.
Even in retrospect, if I was starting it all over, and I had the choice, I'd do it here.
And certainly being done with the right people, and that is particularly George, who has been an incredible supporter of this institution.
It goes well beyond any self-interest of helping the woodlands, what George is doing.
I mean, he'll not see the return
investment-wise, on what he's put into HARC.
And he has a genuine interest and vision in the institutions that are affiliated with HARC and an appreciation for that and a desire to see this happen.
But I'm convinced that, as a nation, we have to discover a new way to compete or we're not going to be competitive.
I think it's already happening to us.
the bright people that we have, whether they're in the academic sector, the industry sector, or the government sector, there's about 2%, equivalent with the number I use, 2%.
I call them the 2%ers, that are not fully employed, regardless of which sector they're in.
If they're in the academic sector, industry finds them and hires them as consultants.
Government finds them and uses them in different capacities.
Advisors, whatever.
If they're in the industry sector, they teach a course in the university as a visiting professor or they start something else in their garage.
These are people whose energy level and intellect goes beyond what the institution's normal ability to absorb it and effectively use it is.
And these people typically cause problems in those institutions.
They're the ones, though, by the view of the other 98%, but they're the ones that drag the institutions kicking and screaming into the future.
In an academic environment, there's no synergistic place where these two presenters can come together.

So if you're off consulting for Boeing and you're an aerospace engineer at major university X, then you rarely ever see the engineer from major university Y who also consults for Boeing, unless they happen to put you
the same project, or certainly if they're consulting for McDonnell Douglas.

And in this kind of general sense, this intuitive sense that there's value in bringing a Texas Instruments and a Texas A&M together, a place to more comfortably do that and to learn how to do it more efficiently, more effectively.
is what I think we're missing.
It's not that we need in our toolbox to throw away some tools.
We need to add a new one that's a crescent wrench that can be adjusted to fit the needs of the moment.
And the old traditional ones that always work or usually work on the standard things that society has to do, great.
You still need the set of box ins.
But we've got to have a new kind of a crescent wrench in there that can deal with a changing situation and is adjustable and adaptable.
So this is a different breed of horse.
You're putting together the same corral.
They're the free spirits from academia, from industry, and government.
And let me tell you how it's begun to work already.
You get a guy like Russ Hewson.
who's a professor of physics at Texas A&M.
He was recruited in here from Fermilab as an integral part of the early team that put us in the competition for a super pilot.
And he holds himself up above all others as a scientist interested in basic physics, but singularly does one of the best jobs around here of moving his technology.
that spins out of pursuing building a system that'll break open a quark so we can understand the fundamental principles of matter.
The magnets that we designed for the super collider have incredibly interesting applications for magnetic resonance imaging.
And we've created a company with Baylor called BayMed, and we're trying to now work with Humana Hospital and Siemens in College Station, as a matter of fact.
produce the first prototype and put it into the private sector for profit.
We're working with Now is this sort of venture capital operation or is this a No, this sure is venture capital.
It's a company that Hark and Baylor decided to create, which we did two years ago.
Did you use the venture capital?
No, no, we put our own money.
We used our own in-house money.
Bill Butler, who's president of Baylor and myself, just got together and he put in his half and I put in my half.
And the company now has the license to the technology, which HARC owns.
And we have a contractual agreement and we license this rather than starting a company here to build MRI magnets to compete with
Brooker and Siemens and Hitachi.
I mean, that's not the way to go in this particular instance.
You license that technology.
But that same magnet, we're working with General Electric and General Dynamics in superconducting magnetic energy storage device.
And now we're forming with Texas A&M a consortium of General Motors and McDonnell Douglas.
to work on maglev train technology using that same mag with a new application, which is technology that HARC owns.
And we've applied for patents on that so that we could have an American-based maglev technology.
Now, here's this physics professor otherwise doing all this.
And it's happening at HARC.
And it wouldn't happen in the physics department.
And here is Monique Talwani.
Who is your contact at Texas A&M as a part of that collaboration?
On the maglev?
Yeah.
It's a guy named Bill Harris, who works in the Texas Transportation Institute.
And he's the Steve Chair of Engineering, the old railroad group.
We looked for five years to fill that chair.
I remember it well.
And I was staying in touch with Charlie Wooten,
who's the director of the Transportation Institute.
And of course, Bill, who's Bill Mobley, who's on my board and president of ADM.
So Bill is in the loop on all of this.
And that's one of the other values, I think, of the structure, the new structure of HARC, is that the presidents of the universities, as members of HARC's board, have the opportunity to declare

early on about their own institutional interest and potential conflict of interest that might occur that we can discuss openly in a board meeting well before we find ourselves in the middle of something that happened at the dean's level
that finally surfaced administratively or at the board level.
So you stripped away a lot of the bureaucracy.
Well, hopefully, I've tried to be efficient in the way we can communicate and decide that this is what we're going to do.
What about from the other side?
You know, you're gifted, perhaps uniquely gifted, in the sense that you had experience with industry and academia.
Is there a
opportunities for somebody like Exxon, for example, to come to HARC and say, we need basic R&D on issue X.
Is that happening?
Oh, yeah.
I was just going to give you an example with Tawani.
And let me give you the history again to show you some of the leverage power of the institution when it can be taken advantage of by one of our collaborative members.
And this worked at A&M with the internment station.
And when the colleges learned how to use it,
really is what leveraged the research growth.
You're far better off if you've got one full-time position to hire two half-time people.
The question is, what do you do with the other two half-times?
Well, if you put them over in the engineering experiment section, and you've got one tenure track position, and that's all otherwise academically you have, hire two people on a half-time budget.
They're going to work full-time anyway.
you're going to get two full-time people.
We all know how we get leveraged like that.
And offload the other half over in the other agency, in the sister institution.
And then watch them for a while.
And then pick the litter.
And that's what engineering was doing for years there.
Well, in the case of Hart now, particularly with Rice, a smaller institution, focused historically
extremely high quality undergraduate education, desires to build its graduate research program.
Hard to attract a Stanford professor who's got a $250 million a year research institution and all the leverage that that brings to an institution with a $20 million a year research.

So in 1985, after I had been here maybe six or eight months, Norm Hackerman called me, who was president of Rice, and said, gee, Skip, you've created a geotechnology research institute to support the energy industry.
Now, I know you're looking for a director.
I've got a chance to hire one of the top five geophysicists in the world, a guy named Mike Talwani, who was the first director of Lamont at Columbia, who was
chief scientist of Gulf, and when Chevron bought Gulf, he didn't want to do that, and we want to offer him the Schlumberger chair of geophysics and bring him to Rice.
But I can't pay him enough to get him out of that chair, and I can't get him anyway because the scope of the research and the opportunity to develop a major research program is just too limited.
But if he's at heart and he can develop and direct the Geotechnology Research Institute,
Then the combination of Rice and Hart together is very intriguing and interesting.
And if you could pay a third of his salary, I'll pay two thirds of his salary out of the chair.
And then together, we can pay the salaries that are required.
And I'll commit as president of Rice to put him at Hart for 100% time for the first three years to help get the problem solved.
That sounds like a deal.
There was, and we did it.

But look at the advantage to Texas, to America, so that you can keep this kind of productive talent moving and excited and challenged to grow rather than just say, oh, well, okay, for this phase of my life, I'll just go be a professional and kind of throttle back.
We don't need throttle back.
We need throttle forward in America.
The competitive heat on the street out there is tough.
And...
You know, HARC is not unfolding as I thought it would five years ago in the details.
Overall, I couldn't be happier.
We're well in the window of expectation, maybe somewhat above the center part.
The structure, I couldn't have written it down five years ago.
It took me three years to figure out where I thought it needed to do by just on-the-job training.
There isn't a recipe to follow.
I mean, I can't study what somebody else did here.
I can read about SRI, which I've done, about RTI, and study the relationships between a federally funded lab like Lincoln and MIT and try to get the best of all of that.
But we're doing something here from scratch.
This is empirically being built, in my mind.
And I'm just flying by the seat of my pants and trying to use all the good talent and advice on my board and other places I can get.
And you see yourself primarily as a facilitator of innovation, of new ideas?
In part, but not primarily.
It's hard to come up with a real simple way to say what we're primarily... You're not in research, I mean, technically.
Oh, yes, we are.
You're in research.
Yes, we are.
Yes, we are.
And what...
So you take a guy now like Andy Blanchard.
who's just replaced David Norton as director of the Star Center.
And he just made full professor tenure at UT Arlington.
Bright, high energy, two percenter.
He has that same feeling about America, that he can't put to work the talents and the energy that's in him
Within the framework.
Within the framework of where he is to deliver what he knows or what he wants to try to deliver for the country.
Mitch Eggers just joined us from MIT in Lincoln.
Was the number one PhD student at Texas A&M eight years ago in electrical engineering.
Incredible reviews from MIT.
What?
Just picked up the phone.
six months ago and called his major professor, John Painter, an old colleague and friend of mine at A&M, and says, I've got to get out of here.
This place isn't going to hold together.
These people up here just think the federal government is going to be able to continue to send money.
And I've been screaming this other story, and nobody understands it.
Painter said, why don't you call Skip Porter?
And he called me.
I said, come down and let's talk.
And I listened to him in here in my office for an hour while he said to me what I've been trying to say to you.
And I said, why don't you come on down here?
You found it.
And he's here now.
He could be anywhere.
Now Rice is going to suck him up and make a joint appointment.
But this will be his primary place.
And he'll outlet and stay in touch.
I've got on the Rice faculty.
I don't want to lose my academic ties.
I don't want to lose that.
And you have someone's man in you that you have a similar arrangement with, don't you?
Some new person that we've...
acquired there?
Well, of course, Russ Hewson, the director of the Accelerator Center, is a faculty member.
Oh, and we also have Dimitri Nonopoulos.
Well, I'll tell you the story of Dimitri.
George may have already told you this.
He loves to tell it.
No.
Well, I and him hired him from Wisconsin.
And Dimitri is one of the top theoretical
astral particle physicist in the world, was mentioned in scientists as a possible recipient for the Nobel Prize in physics this year.
And he came to College Station with his wife.
